message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Past, Present, and Future of Aerial Robotic Manipulators
Paper Abstract: This article analyzes the evolution and current trends in aerial robotic manipulation, comprising helicopters, conventional underactuated multirotors, and multidirectional thrust platforms equipped with a wide variety of robotic manipulators capable of physically interacting with the environment. It also covers cooperative aerial manipulation and interconnected actuated multibody designs. The review is completed with developments in teleoperation, perception, and planning. Finally, a new generation of aerial robotic manipulators is presented with our vision of the future.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Feature (computer vision) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature_(computer_vision)"},{"title":"Computer vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision"},{"title":"Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conference_on_Computer_Vision_and_Pattern_Recognition"},{"title":"Bag-of-words model in computer vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bag-of-words_model_in_computer_vision"},{"title":"Category:Computer vision software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Computer_vision_software"},{"title":"Category:All Computer Vision articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:All_Computer_Vision_articles"},{"title":"Video imprint (computer vision) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_imprint_(computer_vision)"},{"title":"Template talk:Feature detection (computer vision) navbox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Feature_detection_(computer_vision)_navbox"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_talk:Computer_vision"},{"title":"Active vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_vision"}]

## Computer Vision Overview

The scientific discipline of computer vision is concerned with the theory behind artificial systems that extract information from images.(no content)Computer vision is an interdisciplinary field that deals with how computers can be made to gain high-level understanding from digital images or videos, and from the perspective of engineering, it seeks to automate tasks that the human visual system can do.

### What Computer Vision Involves

Computer vision tasks include methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing, and understanding digital images, and extraction of high-dimensional data from the real world in order to produce numerical or symbolic information, such as in the form of decisions.(no content)Image data can take many forms, such as video sequences, views from multiple cameras, multi-dimensional data from a 3D scanner, or 3D point clouds from LiDaR sensors.

### Key Subdisciplines

Subdisciplines of computer vision include scene reconstruction, object detection, event detection, activity recognition, video tracking, object recognition, 3D pose estimation, learning, indexing, motion estimation, visual servoing, 3D scene modeling, and image restoration.

### Historical Development

In the late 1960s, computer vision began at universities that were pioneering artificial intelligence and was meant to mimic the human visual system as a stepping stone to endowing robots with intelligent behavior.(no content)The advancement of Deep Learning techniques has brought further life to the field of computer vision.

Links: [{"title":"Helicopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helicopter"},{"title":"Helicopter parent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helicopter_parent"},{"title":"Attack helicopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attack_helicopter"},{"title":"Ingenuity (helicopter) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ingenuity_(helicopter)"},{"title":"List of United States military helicopters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_military_helicopters"},{"title":"List of helicopter prison escapes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_helicopter_prison_escapes"},{"title":"I Sexually Identify as an Attack Helicopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Sexually_Identify_as_an_Attack_Helicopter"},{"title":"MD Helicopters MH-6 Little Bird - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MD_Helicopters_MH-6_Little_Bird"},{"title":"Helicopter carrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helicopter_carrier"},{"title":"Airbus Helicopters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airbus_Helicopters"}]

I've performed a web search for "Helicopter" and found comprehensive information about helicopters. Here are the key findings:

## Basic Definition and Capabilities

A helicopter is a type of rotorcraft in which lift and thrust are supplied by horizontally spinning rotors. This allows the helicopter to take off and land vertically, to hover, and to fly forward, backward and laterally.

## Etymology

The English word helicopter is adapted from the French word hélicoptère, coined by Gustave Ponton d'Amécourt in 1861, which originates from the Greek helix, "helix, spiral, whirl, convolution" and pteron "wing".

## Common Names

English language nicknames for "helicopter" include "chopper", "copter", "heli", and "whirlybird". In the United States military, the common slang is "helo".

## Rotor Systems

The rotor system, or more simply rotor, is the rotating part of a helicopter that generates lift. Most helicopters have a single main rotor, but torque created by its aerodynamic drag must be countered by an opposed torque.(no content)The tail rotor pushes or pulls against the tail to counter the torque effect, and this has become the most common configuration for helicopter design, usually at the end of a tail boom.

The search results also provide information about specialized helicopters including attack helicopters, military helicopters, helicopter carriers, and even NASA's Ingenuity Mars helicopter.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicles:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Technical Characteristics

A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous (capable of operating without human input) drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier (the precursor to the aircraft carrier) in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions, and detection of illegal hunting.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicles:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Technical Characteristics

A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous (capable of operating without human input) drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier (the precursor to the aircraft carrier) in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions, and detection of illegal hunting.

Web search results for query: "Aerial Robotic Manipulator"

Links: [{"title":"Aerial robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerial_robotics"},{"title":"Mobile manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_manipulator"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Manipulator (device) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulator_(device)"},{"title":"International Aerial Robotics Competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Aerial_Robotics_Competition"},{"title":"Articulated robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Articulated_robot"},{"title":"Outline of robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_robotics"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_systems"},{"title":"Serial manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial_manipulator"},{"title":"Tactical Robotics Cormorant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tactical_Robotics_Cormorant"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Aerial Robotic Manipulators:

## Overview

An aerial robotic manipulator combines two key technologies: aerial robots, which are usually referred to as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and manipulators, which are devices used to manipulate materials without direct physical contact by the operator.

## Practical Applications

A notable example is the Tactical Robotics Cormorant, which is equipped with remotely controlled manipulator arms and can be used for inspections, maintenance operations or repairs, flying above dangerous zones such as nuclear reactors and areas contaminated by chemical plant leaks. Examples of uses include replacing damaged insulators on power lines, pumping heavy water into pools covering uranium rods inside damaged nuclear reactors, fixing leaking pipes or repairing areas under bridges or marine structures that have suffered corrosion damage, and agricultural spraying.

## Key Characteristics

Mobile robotic systems combine the mobility offered by a mobile platform and dexterity offered by the manipulator, with the mobile platform offering an extended workspace to the manipulator and more degrees of freedom to operate in. However, the operation of such a system is challenging because of the many degrees of freedom and the unstructured environment that it performs in.

Aerial robotic manipulators represent an emerging technology with significant potential for performing complex tasks in hazardous or difficult-to-reach environments.

Web search results for query: "Motion planning"

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 2.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_2.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning configuration space road map path.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_configuration_space_road_map_path.svg"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Category:Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Topological complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_complexity"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of motion planning based on the search results:

## What is Motion Planning?

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration S and a goal configuration G, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.(no content)The robot and obstacle geometry is described in a 2D or 3D workspace, while the motion is represented as a path in (possibly higher-dimensional) configuration space.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video game, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

## Key Approaches

**Grid-Based Algorithms:** Grid-based approaches overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point. At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within Cfree (this is tested with collision detection). This discretizes the set of actions, and search algorithms (like A*) are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

**Sampling-Based Algorithms:** Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions (robotic manipulators, biological molecules, animated digital characters, and legged robots).

## Real-Time Path Planning

Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment.

Links: [{"title":"Robotic arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_arm"},{"title":"European Robotic Arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Robotic_Arm"},{"title":"Mechanical arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_arm"},{"title":"File:European Robotic Arm IVA EVA.jpg","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:European_Robotic_Arm_IVA_EVA.jpg"},{"title":"Industrial robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_robot"},{"title":"Arm solution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arm_solution"},{"title":"Manipulator (device) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulator_(device)"},{"title":"Advanced Robotics for Manufacturing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Robotics_for_Manufacturing"},{"title":"Can't Help Myself (Sun Yuan and Peng Yu) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Can't_Help_Myself_(Sun_Yuan_and_Peng_Yu)"},{"title":"Snake-arm robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snake-arm_robot"}]

I've completed a web search for "Robotic Arm". Here's what I found:

## Definition and Basics

A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm; the arm may be the sum total of the mechanism or may be part of a more complex robot.(no content)The links of such a manipulator are connected by joints allowing either rotational motion (such as in an articulated robot) or translational (linear) displacement.

## Key Components

The terminus of the kinematic chain of the manipulator is called the end effector and it is analogous to the human hand.(no content)A serial robot arm can be described as a chain of links that are moved by joints which are actuated by motors, and an end-effector, also called a robot hand, can be attached to the end of the chain.

## Types of Robotic Arms

There are several types, including:
- Cartesian robot: Used for pick and place work, application of sealant, assembly operations, handling machine tools and arc welding. It is a robot whose arm has three prismatic joints, whose axes are coincident with a Cartesian coordinator.
- Articulated robot: Used for assembly operations, diecasting, fettling machines, gas welding, arc welding and spray-painting. It is a robot whose arm has at least three rotary joints.

## Major Manufacturers

Four notable manufacturers of robotic arms include FANUC, ABB, Yaskawa, and KUKA.

## Applications

Robotic arms are used in industrial manufacturing, space exploration, surgery, and many other fields. The Curiosity and Perseverance rovers on the planet Mars also use robotic arms. Additionally, Perseverance has a smaller sample caching arm hidden inside its body below the rover in its caching assembly.

Web search results for query: "Teleoperation"

Links: [{"title":"Teleoperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teleoperation"},{"title":"Telerobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telerobotics"},{"title":"Remote surgery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_surgery"},{"title":"Telepresence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telepresence"},{"title":"Raymond Goertz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Goertz"},{"title":"Presence: Teleoperators & Virtual Environments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presence:_Teleoperators_&_Virtual_Environments"},{"title":"Remote manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_manipulator"},{"title":"Talk:Telepresence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Telepresence"},{"title":"Telehaptics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telehaptics"},{"title":"Optimus (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimus_(robot)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about teleoperation:

## Definition

Teleoperation (or remote operation) indicates operation of a system or machine at a distance.(no content)It is similar in meaning to the phrase "remote control" but is usually encountered in research, academia and technology.

## Applications

Teleoperation has diverse applications across multiple fields:

- **Hazardous Environments**: Industrial machinery is often operated remotely, particularly in hazardous environments. Examples include the construction of the Object Shelter or sarcophagus at Chernobyl after the Chernobyl accident, and removal of debris after hazardous rock slides.

- **Robotics and Exploration**: Remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) are extensively used in hazardous environments (i.e. radioactive environments, contaminated environments, minefields, deep oceans).

- **Autonomous Vehicles**: Most leading companies in the industry believe that to bridge the gap between current self-driving capabilities and the requirements needed for widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles, there is a need to have teleoperation capabilities for assisting self-driving cars, in situations of 'edge cases.'

- **Medical Surgery**: Remote surgery (also known as cybersurgery or telesurgery) is the ability for a doctor to perform surgery on a patient even though they are not physically in the same location.

- **Entertainment**: Teleoperation is now moving into the hobby industry with first-person view (FPV) equipment. FPV equipment mounted on hobby cars, planes and helicopters give a TV-style transmission back to the operator, extending the range of the vehicle to greater than line-of-sight range.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Multirotor"

Links: [{"title":"Multirotor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multirotor"},{"title":"Quadcopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadcopter"},{"title":"Hybrid drone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_drone"},{"title":"Category:Multirotor helicopters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multirotor_helicopters"},{"title":"Radio-controlled helicopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio-controlled_helicopter"},{"title":"Tiltrotor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiltrotor"},{"title":"Volocopter VC2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volocopter_VC2"},{"title":"Freefly Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freefly_Systems"},{"title":"MultiGP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MultiGP"},{"title":"Toroidal propeller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toroidal_propeller"}]

Here are the search results for "Multirotor":

## Definition and Overview

A multirotor or multicopter is a rotorcraft with more than two lift-generating rotors.(no content)An advantage of multirotor aircraft is the simpler rotor mechanics required for flight control, as they often use fixed-pitch blades with control of vehicle motion achieved by varying the relative speed of each rotor.

## Applications and Types

Due to their ease of both construction and control, multirotor aircraft are frequently used in radio control aircraft and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) (drone) projects in which the names tricopter, quadcopter, hexacopter and octocopter are frequently used to refer to 3-, 4-, 6- and 8-rotor rotorcraft, respectively.

## Characteristics

Most multirotors are small, with First-person view (radio control) and battery power which limits their range, endurance, and payload.(no content)Multirotors are generally more affordable, easier to construct, and simpler to operate than RC helicopters.

## Notable Examples

Volocopter designs are a series of German prototype electric multicopters with 18 rotors, the first electric multicopter in the world to achieve crewed flight.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Most multirotors are small, with First-person view (radio control) and battery power which limits their range, endurance, and payload.(no content)Multirotors are generally more affordable, easier to construct, and simpler to operate than RC helicopters.

## Notable Examples

Volocopter designs are a series of German prototype electric multicopters with 18 rotors, the first electric multicopter in the world to achieve crewed flight.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks are complete. Here's a summary of the analysis:

## Paper Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Key Findings:**

The paper "Past, Present, and Future of Aerial Robotic Manipulators" is classified as a **survey** article. The abstract clearly indicates it reviews existing work: "This article **analyzes the evolution and current trends**" and "**The review is completed** with developments..."

**Extracted Triples (8 entities):**

The analysis identified 8 key technologies and methodologies explicitly mentioned in the title and abstract:

1. **Aerial robotics** - The core subject matter combining robot design and control for aerial platforms
2. **Helicopter** - One of the primary platform types analyzed
3. **Multirotor** - Conventional underactuated multirotors for aerial manipulation
4. **Robotic arm** - The manipulator component for physical interaction
5. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** - The foundational platform technology
6. **Teleoperation** - Remote control methodology for aerial manipulators
7. **Motion planning** - Planning algorithms for autonomous navigation
8. **Computer vision** - Perception techniques for environmental sensing

All entities are marked as **"uses"** (since this is a survey reviewing existing technologies), with appropriate entity types (3 artifacts, 3 methods, 1 tool, 1 concept).

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED

All triples have been validated against Wikipedia, with correct URLs and proper JSON structure.
